awd_titl_txt: OP:   Collaborative Research:   Non-Hamiltonian Wave Dynamics in Atomic & Optical Models
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focusses on the effects of energy gain and/or loss when waves propagate through non-linear media. The simplest kinds of wave motion exhibit a property called isochronism which was first observed by Galileo: The frequency of oscillation of the wave is independent of its amplitude (or size). Wave media in which this simple behavior is observed are called "linear". Non-linear media are also known, in which the frequency of the wave varies with its amplitude. If the medium is also dispersive (like a prism), then waves with different frequency will travel with different speed. The combined effects of non-linearity and dispersion can be quite striking, as with the formation of solitons - stable wave patterns that propagate through the medium without changing shape. A central focus of this work is to explore how solitons and other coherent structures that form in non-linear media, such as vortices, are responsible for the localization and transport of energy and information. If the medium through which the wave propagates is dissipative, then energy is lost to friction or radiation, and so stabilizing the flow of energy and information requires energy input (gain). The work will focus especially on the interplay of gain and loss in current experimental, theoretical, and computational investigations into the behavior of non-linear media formed from ultra-cold atomic vapors.  

This project involves the comprehensive examination of some selected key aspects within this class of systems. The study is based on variants of one of the most prototypical and most relevant models for the evolution of nonlinear waves: the nonlinear Schroedinger (NLS) equation. The NLS equation is at the heart of a wide variety of physical phenomena including, but not limited to, optical fibers, condensed matter physics, plasma waves, and deep water freak/rogue waves in fluid mechanics. In particular, the group will study the effects of gain and loss within the realm of (A) optical systems that have the so-called Parity-Time reversal (PT) symmetry, and possess a delicate balance between external gain and intrinsic loss that can robustly sustain the existence and propagation of coherent structures, (B) finite temperature Bose-Einstein condensates which have been proposed as candidates for sustaining/processing quantum information that could potentially realize the next generation of computational architectures, and finally, (C) exciton-polariton condensates, which provide another pristine and very accessible experimental setting for the manipulation of macroscopic quantum mechanics. Within these systems, the group will explore the interplay of the intrinsic scales induced by nonlinearity and dispersion and the extrinsic ones, stemming from gain and loss, and how this interplay affects the existence, stability and dynamics of different coherent structures that are the building blocks of information storage and processing.  Within this program, the group expects to generate mathematical models and methods, as well as computational techniques, that will not only shed light to these particular atomic and optical applications and their experimental observations, but which may also be of broader use for the study of other non-conservative systems.

por.por_cntn:
The topic of Nonlinear Waves is one that is important over a wide range scales in the world around us. Wave structures appear in the pressure pulses that we feel inside us, they appear in phenomena at the scale of our environment (such as wave patterns on the beach or in the ocean) and they arise even at scales as large as that of our planet (an example being the localization of energy in the Great Red Spot of Jupiter).This topic has concerned scientists intensely since the 19th century, starting from the theme of water waves and the dynamics of fluid motions. A predominant feature that has been identified therein is that the interplay of dispersion effects (spreading the energy) and nonlinear effects (localizing it) lead to the formation of solitary wave patterns when these two effects balance each other perfectly.

While these ideas originally appeared in water waves, and subsequently re-emerged some 60 years later in computational studies of nonlinear models, more recently they have become central to a series of Nobel-prize winning discoveries concerning the topic of lasers (1968 Prize) and that of Bose-Einstein condensates -BECs- (2001 Prize). The former is well-known due to its generic impact on our lives, while the latter emerges when cooling, say, alkali gases (such as Rubidium, Sodium, Lithium etc.) to the lowest temperatures of our Universe, a genuinely ultracold setting. This is a remarkable platform for exploring phenomena of quantum mechanics at the mesoscopic scale i.e., over scales of microns (0.000001 m) and milliseconds (0.001 s).

While the prototypical optical systems concerning the laser and atomic systems of BECs may be energy-conserving, in realistic scenarios, there are numerous reasons why energy may be dissipated away. In the case of light, there is optical loss which is balanced via gain by amplifiers. In the case of atoms, thermal or quantum effects turn the atoms to different populations and thus also contribute to an effective dissipation which, in turn, needs to be replenished for the system to maintain equilibrium.

In the realm of the present work, we studied a wide range of such systems. We focused on electrical systems featuring gain and loss (as a proxy for corresponding optical settings) and illustrated scenarios under which they may feature breathing wave excitations. We also examined condensates of so-called polaritons that explicitly feature gain and loss mechanisms and illustrated that they can produce swirls (vortices) that interact in new and unexpected ways. Finally, we explored the effect of thermal and quantum fluctuations on atomic systems illustrating how the former may lead to pathways for the disappearance of nonlinear wave patterns, while the latter may lead to the population of higher (orbital) quantum states. Importantly, both lead to substantial modifications of the behaviors observed at the simplest leading-order models and hence at higher temperatures or low enough atom numbers these more elaborate models that we examined need to be suitably taken into account in the theoretical modeling (and numerical computations) of realistic experimental settings.

In addition to these efforts, we were able to tackle a variety of additional topics including

a) the examination of atomic systems of many components in BECs and the novel opportunities these may present in terms of wave patterns;

b) the exploration of mathematical wave systems stemming from plasmas, elastic media and others, giving rise to insufficiently studied wave equations;

c) the identification of wave patterns especially in higher dimensions via novel computational techniques that we developed and presented to the community.

The resulting theoretical and computational tools and techniques are highly promising towards the development of an arsenal of methods for the study of nonlinear waves in conservative and dissipative systems. This is an effort that we hope to continue in a number of emerging physical platforms in the near future.
